subsection.title: Motivation for derivatives

introduction.p: We will extend our notion of slope to allow ourselves to make precise descriptions of how values of all functions, not just linear functions, change.

subsection.p: Average and instantaneous rates of change. Consider the function f(t), perhaps describing the position of a frog while it crosses a pond, graphed below. Assume that f is measured in meters and t in seconds.

subsection.title: The limit definiton of the derivative

introduction.p: We will extend our notion of slope to allow ourselves to make precise descriptions of how values of all functions, not just linear functions, change.

subsection.p:
The slope of the secant line that connects the points (a, f(a)) and (b, f(b)) on the graph of f(t) is,
m_{\text{sec}} =\dfrac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a} = \dfrac{\Delta f}{\Delta t},
which we call the average rate of change of f(t) between t = a and t = b, in meters per second. By bringing b closer and closer to a, our secant line ecomes a tangent line. To do this we introduce a limit,
m_{\text{tan}} = \lim_{b\to a} \dfrac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}
which we call the instantaneous rate of change of f(t) at t = a, again in meters per second.

statement.p:
Last time in our limit definition, we used the limit as \Delta t \to 0. We will briefly show why that is equivalent to the approach above and computationally easier. Since \Delta t = b a, we have b = a+\Delta t. Taking b \to a is the same as taking \Delta t \to 0. Substitute b = a+\Delta t in the definition for m_{\text{tan}} and simplify,
\begin{aligned}[t] m_{\text{tan}} \amp = \lim_{b\to a}\dfrac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\\ amp = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0}\dfrac{f(a+\Delta t)-f(a)}{(a+\Delta t)-a}\\ m_{\text{tan}} amp = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0}\dfrac{f(a+\Delta t)-f(a)}{\Delta t} \end{aligned}

Rather than using the two symbols required to write \Delta t, we often use a single symbol h to denote the change from a to b in the definition (and in the picture above). This amounts to saying that b= a+h rather than b=a+\Delta t (since h=\Delta t), so that the derivative of f(x) at x=a is f'(a) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\dfrac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}

For a function f(x), the derivative is written using the notation
\text{prime}\rightarrow f'(x) = \dfrac{df}{dx} \leftarrow \text{differential},
and is to be interpreted in any of the three following ways,
intuitively as the instantaneous rate of change
geometrically as the slope of the tangent line
mathematically as \displaystyle f'(x) = \dfrac{df}{dx} = \lim_{h\to0}\dfrac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}

A function f is differentiable at the point a if the function has a well-defined tangent line with finite slope at point a. If we say a function is differentiable without mentioning a particular point, we mean it is differentiable everywhere.
Functions fail to be differentiable at points on the graph with jumps, corners, and vertical tangents. See graphs from the earlier lecture as examples of discontinuities.

A function f has a critical point at x if f(x) = 0 or if the derivative is not defined at x.

Suppose s(x) = f(x)+g(x) where f and g are both differentiable functions. Then the derivative of the sum is the sum of the derivatives
\begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{ds}{dx} \amp = \dfrac{df}{dx} + \dfrac{dg}{dx},\text{or}\\ s'(x) \amp f'(x) + g'(x) \end{aligned}
Find the derivative of f(x) = x^2 + 3x + 7.

Suppose p(x) = cf(x) where f is differentiable and c is a constant. Then the derivative of a constant times a function is the constant times the derivative of the function, or
\dfrac{d}{dx}\Big(cf(x)\Big) = c\dfrac{d}{dx}\Big(f(x)\Big) = c\dfrac{df}{dx} = cf'(x)
